title: 106_hr388
content: SECTION 1. PROHIBITION. The Secretary of the Interior is prohibited from issuing leases for oil or gas exploration on specified submerged lands. Exploration or extraction is not allowed after lease cancellation, but ongoing activities are permitted under existing leases. The restricted lands include submerged areas within 100 miles of the Outer Continental Shelf. The Act prohibits oil and gas leasing activities on submerged lands near the coastlines of Florida, Georgia, and South Carolina, as well as areas within 175 miles of the Outer Continental Shelf. The Act prohibits oil and gas leasing activities on submerged lands near the coastlines of North Carolina, Virginia, Maryland, and Delaware within specific distances from the Outer Continental Shelf. The Act extends the moratorium on oil and gas leasing activities to submerged lands near the coastlines of New Jersey and New York within 125 miles of the Outer Continental Shelf. The Act extends the moratorium on oil and gas leasing activities to submerged lands near the coastlines of Connecticut, Rhode Island, and Massachusetts within certain distances from the Outer Continental Shelf. The Act extends the moratorium on oil and gas leasing activities to submerged lands near the coastlines of Connecticut, Rhode Island, and Massachusetts within certain distances from the Outer Continental Shelf, including specific blocks surrounding Georges Bank identified by the Department of the Interior. The Act extends the moratorium on oil and gas leasing activities to submerged lands within 100 miles of the Outer Continental Shelf, including specific blocks identified in protraction diagrams. The Act extends the moratorium on oil and gas leasing activities to submerged lands within 100 miles of the Outer Continental Shelf for several states including New Hampshire, Maine, California, and Oregon. The Act extends the moratorium on oil and gas leasing activities to submerged lands within 100 miles of the Outer Continental Shelf for Washington and Alaska, excluding portions of the Central or Western Gulf of Mexico planning areas. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to cancel any lease or permit in effect. The Secretary of the Interior can cancel leases or permits in specified areas, entitling the lessee to compensation. The areas include lands south of 26 degrees north latitude and east of 86 degrees west longitude, and the North Aleutian Basin planning area. The Secretary must report to Congress on compensating leaseholders on specific blocks within 9 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of the Interior can cancel leases or permits in specified areas, entitling the lessee to compensation. This includes blocks 511, 553, 554, 555, 597, 598, 599, 640, 641, and 642 on protraction diagram NI 18-2 of the Universal Transverse Mercator Grid System. Compensation procedures outlined in the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act may include credits on Federal royalties on producing Outer Continental Shelf leases.
